author: arnetheduck
content: hey all - I'm curious, does anyone have any resources on why ethereum ended up using uncompressed secp keys mosty? not that they appear very often in their raw form, but still - they do for example form a part of the rlpx authentication etc - my best guess would perhaps be performance when used as an input to produce an address, but is there more to it?

author: sky.cactus
content: <@449019668296892420> I want to say it has to do with the fact that Ethereum does not include the signer address or public key, and so it needs to be able to extract that from signature + signed data.

author: sky.cactus
content: And I think that process is a tad harder (can have multiple answers) if you have a compressed signature?

author: axic3354
content: That is actually a good question, we could consider using compressed signatures in the new transaction format.

author: axic3354
content: One slim reason against it would be the inconsistency with the ecrecover precompile, but that is already inconsistent because it has less restrictions about the signature.

author: arnetheduck
content: indeed, recoverable signatures are used - but an ethereum address is the hash of the uncompressed public key, not compressed - likewise, the rlpx negotiation transfers an uncompressed public key over the wire to negotiate the ecdh secret

author: sky.cactus
content: Addresses from uncompressed public key just saves you a step.

author: sky.cactus
content: Compressing first seems like wasted effort and complexity.

author: sky.cactus
content: Not sure about the RLPx negotiation.  Maybe just because uncompressed was used elsewhere?

author: arnetheduck
content: also, afair secp only has a compressed encoding for keys, not signatures

author: sky.cactus
content: Hmm, perhaps.  It has been a while since I wrote a secp library.  ðŸ˜¬

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe it was Bitcoin that had compressed signatures?

author: arnetheduck
content: compression here is a bit of a funny word as well - the compressed public keys are slower mostly on deserialization  because the extra coordinate that is removed during "compression" needs to be calculated

author: sky.cactus
content: That is what I was thinking of (compressed signature).
